text: - Hi, and welcome back

to our masterclass on
data governance at AWS.
And I'm Kevin Lewis.
So now let's talk about governance
of analytics and reporting,

because, you know, we
can do a lot of hard work

to get the quality of our
data where it needs to be.
We can get it integrated,
we can support the business initiatives,

and we can have all
the data in a condition

necessary to be successful
with the business,
and succeed with all of that.

Then we open up the data
to the analytics community.

And if there's no
governance or consistency
around the analytics side of it,
we can then lose the perception of quality
that we've worked so hard to create

because everybody's
creating the same reports
over and over again,

and there's a bunch of
overlap and inconsistency,

and, you know, spreadsheets
here and dashboards there,
and all of that.
So it is important as a part of,
or at least related to,
the data governance program

to also think about
governing the analytics work.
Now, again, much like data governance,
it should be considered an enabler.

Governance should not be
seen as a restriction.

It should be seen as
something that accelerates
the work of analytics,

because what you're doing
is you're just improving

the quality of the reporting
and analytics capability,
and, importantly, you're not burdening
the analytics community

to build the same reports
over and over again.

You're just making
their lives a lot easier

so that they can focus on the
truly innovative and new work

that they need to do
to get their jobs done.

So when we organize the
analytics community,

it's gonna be very much
like what we talked about

in distributing responsibilities
for data governance.

We wanna decentralize but
not decentralize so much
that we create splintering.
So how do we resolve this?
So in any organization, you will have,
typically you'll have analysts

in various departments
throughout the company,
maybe in operations research

or in marketing or in
strategy development.

And really these days, just
about every department,
if not all of them,

is gonna have at least
some focus on analytics,
either as an element of existing jobs
or full-time jobs throughout the company.
And so the first thing that you wanna do
is at least get an understanding
of where all this work is taking place.
Get an understanding of what are the roles

that are out there as it relates
to analytics and reporting,

and who is doing what
work and for what purpose?
And then what you're gonna often find
is that there's gonna be maybe one or two
of these organizations
that may be a suitable candidate

to introduce the concept of
a more coordinated community.

For example, in a lot of the
companies that we work with,

in the finance department
you will find a group,
something along the lines
of financial performance and analytics,
something like that.

And you'll find that they
do a lot of, of course,
financial centric reporting,

but they almost always
are involved in reporting
beyond just the numbers,

but those things that influence
the financial numbers.
And this is a group that already serves

the wider community of business
decision makers and analysts
throughout the company.

So that's just an example
of finding an organization
within the company that we can say,

"Okay, this group is already
sort of a hub of analytics.
Why don't we take this to the next level,
and we make this group a coordination hub
for the wider analytics community
throughout the organization?"
Maybe it starts with just, you know,

building out capabilities and
providing a forum for people

to share best practices and
using tools and all of that.
But at the same time, what it can also do
is make sure that it is establishing

what we can think of
as certified analytics,
or certified reporting,
meaning that what are the core elements
of analytics and reporting
that are gonna be used

by the widest variety of business
areas within the company?
And of course, I have to say that,
"Okay, where do we start with this?"

Well, why not start with the
major business initiatives
that are driving everything else?
So as we build out both the community

and we build out some
of this shared reporting
and analytics capability,
it is very helpful to take the energy

that's associated with these
top funded business initiatives

and build reporting and analytics
within those initiatives,

but position them to
be certified analytics

that should not have to be
recreated over and over again
by the wider community.
And so, again, we wanna balance
centralization and decentralization.
It does not mean that all of the analysts
throughout the company have to, you know,

report directly into and
co-locate with the central team.

You can have all of the analysts
all throughout the company
stay right where they are,

and they can stay very close
to their internal customers
to get to be very familiar
with the business needs in that area,

to serve their constituents
as proactively as possible
with minimal bottlenecks.

But they'll just have
this added connection
both to each other as a community
and to the central organization.
And these can be dotted line relationships
or straight line relationships,

but we would still
typically, in either case,

we would typically advocate
that the analysts stay close
to the constituents that they serve,

even if they have a
straight line relationship
to this central analytics community.
Because again, it's this balance
between centralized and decentralized.
Maximize the empowerment

but reduce the amount of
work that they have to do
because it's now taken care of for them.

And so you're accelerating
and enhancing their capability
rather than creating a bottleneck.
And you can do things like, you know,

standardize on tools and provide
help to the wider community
about which tools are the right tools
to use in particular cases.

There's also a link to
application development.
So when we are building core metrics
and core analytics capability,

we wanna have a relationship
between this team
and a team within IT

that helps to embed
analytics inside applications
because a lot of this same capability
that we build for standard metrics,

reporting dashboards, and
so on for the community,

for analytics these are
the same kinds of things

that can be embedded
directly into applications

as they are developed, so
there's a link there as well.
So let me give you an example here,
and this is just to show that, you know,

you really have to look
within your organization
at what is already happening today
and who is the closest to this,

to being this central
hub of analytics already,
and maybe play off of that.
So in a financial services organization
that I was working with,

there was actually a
chief marketing officer.

Now, normally you would
not look to marketing

as a central hub of reporting
for the entire organization,
except for marketing reporting,
but not for, you know, all analytics.

However, in this case, the
chief marketing officer
was very interested in,

it was a long-time
employee of the company,
he had a lot of interest
in the success of the company as a whole

in addition to his role as
chief marketing officer.

So he was already establishing
a chief data office
within his organization.
And as a part of that,

he was also building out a
chief analytics organization.
And this is something
that we absolutely advocated in his case

because that organization
was already being positioned,
and frankly, informally, a lot of analysts

throughout the organization
were already reaching out

to his organization for help
and guidance and support
and all of those things.
So kind of unofficially,

his organization was playing
the role of this analytics hub
that we wanna build.

So what we advocated was
to more formalize that.
Now, the important thing

was they did not make it
a part of the CMO office.
They created something
called a chief data and analytics office
within the marketing group.

And the intention was always
to split that out later.
So this is just to show, again,
I gave the example of, you know,
typically you'll see something like this
in a finance organization,

but you should look for
it wherever it lives.

And you may end up creating
something completely new

that is pulled from all
these various groups.

But it's important to
at least be conscious

of the communities that
are already in place today.

And if you're not gonna
sort of pick one as the hub,

at least sort of bring them
along as part of the process
and talk about how they can participate
and contribute to this.
So that's distributing responsibilities
within the analytics community.
And again, it's a very important part
of the overall success of data governance.
